               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/authorization-boundary/diagrams/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/authorization-boundary/diagrams/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>

                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/authorization-boundary/diagrams/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/authorization-boundary/diagram/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/authorization-boundary/diagrams/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>

                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/authorization-boundary/diagrams/links/href" class="toc6 head">href</h6>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                           can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                           a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                           which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                           that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource

                           of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location

         <section class="json-obj">
            <div class="header">
               <div>
                  <h3 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture" class="toc3 head">network-architecture</h3>Network ArchitectureA description of the system's network architecture, optionally
                  supplemented by diagrams that illustrate the network architecture.Network Architecture
                  DescriptionA summary of the system's network architecture.
                  <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/props</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate

                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have

                        by the associated OSCAL model.

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/diagrams/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/diagrams/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/diagram/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/diagrams/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/diagram/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/diagrams/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                        <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of

                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/network-architecture/diagrams/links/href" class="toc6 head">href</h6>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                           can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                           a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier

                           that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                           is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                           of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                           of the document containing the link.

         <section class="json-obj">
            <div class="header">
               <div>
                  <h3 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow" class="toc3 head">data-flow</h3>Data FlowA description of the logical flow of information within the system and across
                  its boundaries, optionally supplemented by diagrams that illustrate these flows.Data
                  Flow DescriptionA summary of the system's data flow.
                  <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/props</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
                  <p>An array of Link objects</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/links</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
                  <p>An array of Diagram objects</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">object Diagram</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An object  member of array <code>diagrams</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A graphic that provides a visual representation the system, or some aspect of it.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>A diagram must include a <code>link</code> with a rel value of "diagram", who's href references a remote URI or an internal
                              reference within this document containing the diagram.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>RemarksAdditional commentary on the containing object.
                  
                  
                  A given uuid must be assigned only once to a diagram.

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>

                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>

                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">

                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <section class="json-obj">

                           or quality of the property's containing object.

                           value.
                           
                           
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop/@name"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">

                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/name</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or

                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/uuid" class="toc6 head">uuid</h6>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                           this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                           a given location across revisions of the document.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/uuid">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                           document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                           of the document.</p>
                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/ns">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/value" class="toc6 head">value</h6>Property ValueIndicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop/@value"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">

                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.string">string</a> with key <code>value</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/value</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.</p>
                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/class" class="toc6 head">class</h6>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                           property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                           semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class
                           can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a
                           specific class value.

                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/class">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/class</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">string Property Class</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>class</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/props/class</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                           multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/links" class="toc5 head">links</h5>
                        <p>An array of Link objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagrams/links</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                    a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                                 <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                              </div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-party/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-party/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-party/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/props/ns">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-party/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/links/href">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/responsible-parties/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

      <section class="json-obj">
         <div class="header">
            <div>
               <h2 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation" class="toc2 head">system-implementation</h2>System ImplementationProvides information as to how the system is implemented.
               <p>An array of Property objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/props</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Link objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/links</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Leveraged Authorization objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Leveraged Authorization</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>leveraged-authorizations</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/leveraged-authorizations</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A description of another authorized system from which this system inherits capabilities
                     that satisfy security requirements. Another term for this concept is a <em>common control provider</em>. </p>
               </div>
               <p>An array of System User objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object System User</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>users</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A type of user that interacts with the system based on an associated role.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Permissible values to be determined closer to the application, such as by a receiving
                           authority.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Component objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Component</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>components</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies,
                           processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security
                           and/or privacy.</p>
                        <p>The <code>type</code> indicates which of these component types is represented.</p>
                        <p>When defining a <code>service</code> component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more <code>link</code> entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific
                           component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Inventory Item objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Inventory Item</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>inventory-items</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A single managed inventory item within the system.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>A set of <code>inventory-item</code> entries that represent the managed inventory instances of the system.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>RemarksAdditional commentary on the containing object.

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/props/ns" class="toc4 head">ns</h4>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                     organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                     to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                     can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                     This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                     an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                     control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                     uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                     be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                     by the associated OSCAL model.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/props/ns">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/props/ns</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/links/href" class="toc4 head">href</h4>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                     can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                     that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                     a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                     which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                     that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                     is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                     of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                     of the document containing the link.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>

                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/links/href</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                           resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                           containing the link.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/leveraged-authorizations/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/leveraged-authorization/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/leveraged-authorizations/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/leveraged-authorizations/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/leveraged-authorization/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>

                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/leveraged-authorizations/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/user/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">array </p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An array  with key <code>props</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props</p>
                  </div>
               </div>

                        or quality of the property's containing object.
                        
                        A label or descriptor that is tied to a sensitivity or classification marking system.
                        An optional class can be used to define the specific marking system used for the associated
                        value.
                        
                        
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/user/prop/@name"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/user/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/uuid">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
