                     <div class="obj-matrix">

                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a> with key <code>uuid</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/uuid</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/user/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/ns">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/class" class="toc5 head">class</h5>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                        property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the

                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/props/class</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                           </div>
                        </details>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/user/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/links/href">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">

                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/users/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/type" class="toc4 head">type</h4>Component TypeA category describing the purpose of the component.

                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>

                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/ns">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                        property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the

                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/class</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>

            <section class="json-obj">

                  <div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                        </details>

                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/responsible-roles/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>

                        <div class="obj-desc">

                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/responsible-roles/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/responsible-roles/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/responsible-role/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>

                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                           that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                           a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                           which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                           that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                           is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                           of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                           of the document containing the link.

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">

                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of

                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>

                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/responsible-parties/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.

                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                           <div class="remarks">

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/implemented-component/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/props">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/implemented-component/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/props/class" class="toc6 head">class</h6>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of

                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                    a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                                 <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/implemented-component/link"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/links/href" class="toc6 head">href</h6>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                           can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                           a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                           which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                           that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                           is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                           of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                           of the document containing the link.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/implemented-component/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>

                           <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>

                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>

                              <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                 resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document

                              <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within

                                       or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                       and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                       an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                       lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                       consistency.</p>
                                    <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                       was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                       of the containing object.</p>

                              <h7 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-items/implemented-components/responsible-parties/props/ns" class="toc7 head">ns</h7>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                              to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                              can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                              This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                              by the associated OSCAL model.

                              associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>

                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed

            <div>
               <h2 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation" class="toc2 head">control-implementation</h2>Control ImplementationDescribes how the system satisfies a set of controls.Control
               Implementation DescriptionA statement describing important things to know about how
               this set of control satisfaction documentation is approached.
               <p>An array of Set Parameter Value objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Set Parameter Value</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>set-parameters</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/set-parameters</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Identifies the parameter that will be set by the enclosed value.</p>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Control-based Requirement objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Control-based Requirement</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>implemented-requirements</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Describes how the system satisfies an individual control.</p>
               </div>
               
               
               Since multiple set-parameter entries can be provided, each parameter must be set only
               once.
               
               Use of set-parameter in this context, sets the parameter for all related controls
               referenced in an implemented-requirement. If the same parameter is also set in a specific
               implemented-requirement, then the new value will override this value.
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
            </div>
         </div>
         <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation">/system-security-plan/control-implementation</a> in the object map.</p>
         <div class="obj-desc">

               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
               <p>An object  with key <code>control-implementation</code>.</p>
               <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation</p>
            </div>
            <p class="description">Describes how the system satisfies a set of controls.</p>
            <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
               <summary>Remarks</summary>
               <div class="remarks">
                  <p>Use of <code>set-parameter</code> in this context, sets the parameter for all related controls referenced in an <code>implemented-requirement</code>. If the same parameter is also set in a specific <code>implemented-requirement</code>, then the new value will override this value.</p>
               </div>
            </details>
         </div>

               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/control-id">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/control-id</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Control Identifier Reference</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>control-id</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/control-id</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a control with a corresponding <code>id</code> value.</p>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">array </p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An array  with key <code>props</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props</p>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/name" class="toc5 head">name</h5>Property NameA textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic,
                        or quality of the property's containing object.
                        
                        A label or descriptor that is tied to a sensitivity or classification marking system.
                        An optional class can be used to define the specific marking system used for the associated
                        value.
                        
                        
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@name"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/name">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/name</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Name</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>name</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/name</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or
                        quality of the property's containing object.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/uuid">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a> with key <code>uuid</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/uuid</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/value" class="toc5 head">value</h5>Property ValueIndicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@value"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/value">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/value</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Value</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.string">string</a> with key <code>value</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/value</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/class" class="toc5 head">class</h5>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                        property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                        semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class
                        can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a
                        specific class value.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@class"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/class">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/class</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Class</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>class</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/class</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>A <code>class</code> can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of
                              a specific <code>class</code> value.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                     </div>

                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/remarks">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/remarks</a> in the object map.</p>

                     <div class="obj-matrix">

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.markup-multiline">markup-multiline</a> with key <code>remarks</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/remarks</p>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/links" class="toc4 head">links</h4>
                     <p>An array of Link objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/links</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/link"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>

               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">array </p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An array  with key <code>links</code>.</p>

                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/links/href">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>

                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/responsible-roles/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/responsible-roles/links/href" class="toc6 head">href</h6>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/props">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                        </div>
                     </div>
