                        <section class="json-obj">
                           <div class="header">
                              <div>
                                 <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/satisfied/responsible-roles/props" class="toc8 head">props</h8>
                                 <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                 <div class="obj-desc">
                                    <div class="obj-matrix">
                                       <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                                       <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                                       <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                                       <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/satisfied/responsible-roles/props</p>
                                    </div>
                                    <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                       qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                       may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                    <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                       <div class="remarks">
                                          <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                             OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                             or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                             and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                             an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                             lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                             consistency.</p>
                                          <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                             was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                             of the containing object.</p>
                                       </div>
                                    </details>
                                 </div>
                                 <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/satisfied/responsible-role/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                              </div>
                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/satisfied/responsible-roles/props">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/satisfied/responsible-roles/props</a> in the object map.</p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">

                                    organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                    to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                    can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                    This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                    an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                    control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                    uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                    be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined

                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                          OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                          or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                          an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                          lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                          consistency.</p>
                                       <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                          was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                          of the containing object.</p>

                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                 to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                 can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                 This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                 an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                 control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                 uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                 be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                 by the associated OSCAL model.

                                 associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>

                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">

                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/name</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or

                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/uuid" class="toc6 head">uuid</h6>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                           this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                           a given location across revisions of the document.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/uuid">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">

                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/uuid</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                           document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                           of the document.</p>
                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/props/class" class="toc6 head">class</h6>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                           property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                           semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class
                           can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a
                           specific class value.

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/links/href" class="toc6 head">href</h6>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                           can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                           a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                           which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                           that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                           is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                           of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                           of the document containing the link.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>

                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/links/href</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                 resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                 containing the link.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>

                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/implementation-status" class="toc5 head">implementation-status</h5>Implementation StatusIndicates the degree to which the a given control is implemented.Implementation

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export" class="toc5 head">export</h5>ExportIdentifies content intended for external consumption, such as with leveraged
                        organizations.Control Implementation Export DescriptionAn implementation statement
                        that describes the aspects of the control or control statement implementation that
                        can be available to another system leveraging this system.
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <p>An array of Link objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/links</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/props" class="toc6 head">props</h6>
                           <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">
                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>

                              </div>
                              <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                 qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                 may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                       OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                       or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                       and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                       an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                       lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                       consistency.</p>
                                    <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                       was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                       of the containing object.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>

                     <section class="json-obj">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div>
                              <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/props/ns" class="toc7 head">ns</h7>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                              to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                              can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                              This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                              by the associated OSCAL model.
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/props/ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">

                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                              <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/props/ns</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                              associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                    names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                    with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                 <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                    to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>

                        <div class="header">
                           <div>
                              <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/links/href" class="toc7 head">href</h7>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                              can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                              a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                              which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                              that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                              is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                              of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                              of the document containing the link.
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     <section class="json-obj">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div>
                              <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props" class="toc7 head">props</h7>
                              <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                              <div class="obj-desc">
                                 <div class="obj-matrix">
                                    <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                                    <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                                    <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                                    <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props</p>
                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                    qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                    may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                          OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                          or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                          an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                          lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                          consistency.</p>
                                       <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                          was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                          of the containing object.</p>
                                    </div>
                                 </details>
                              </div>
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/provided/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props</a> in the object map.</p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">

                        <section class="json-obj">
                           <div class="header">
                              <div>
                                 <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props/ns" class="toc8 head">ns</h8>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                 to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                 can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                 This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                 an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                 control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                 uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                 be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                 by the associated OSCAL model.
                                 <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/provided/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                              </div>
                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props/ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">
                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                 <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                                 <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props/ns</p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                                 associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                       names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                       with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                    <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                       to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                    <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                        </section>

                                 <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/props/class" class="toc8 head">class</h8>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the

                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                          a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                                       <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                                    </div>
                                 </details>
                              </div>
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/provided/link"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                        <section class="json-obj">
                           <div class="header">
                              <div>
                                 <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/links/href" class="toc8 head">href</h8>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                                 can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                 a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                 which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                 that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                                 is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                                 of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                                 of the document containing the link.
                                 <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/provided/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                              </div>
                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/links/href">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/provided/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>

                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                       that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                    <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                       "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                    <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                       resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document

                                    </div>
                                    <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                       <div class="remarks">
                                          <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                             OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                             or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                             and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                             an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                             lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                             consistency.</p>
                                          <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                             was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                             of the containing object.</p>

                                    organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                    to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                    can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                    This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                    an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                    control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                    uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                    be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                    by the associated OSCAL model.

                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                    qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which

                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                          OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                          or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                          an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                          lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                          consistency.</p>
                                       <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                          was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                          of the containing object.</p>

                                 <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/props/ns" class="toc8 head">ns</h8>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                 to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                 can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                 This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                 an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                 control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                 uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                 be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                 by the associated OSCAL model.

                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                       names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                       with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                    <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                       to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                    <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                        </section>

                        <section class="json-obj">
                           <div class="header">
                              <div>
                                 <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/links/href" class="toc8 head">href</h8>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                                 can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                 a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                 which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                 that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                                 is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                                 of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                                 of the document containing the link.
                                 <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/responsibility/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                                 <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/links/href</p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                       that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                    <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                       "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                    <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                       resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                       containing the link.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                        </section>

                                       <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/responsible-roles/props</p>
                                    </div>
                                    <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                       qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                       may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                    <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                       <div class="remarks">
                                          <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                             OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                             or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                             and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                             an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                             lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                             consistency.</p>
                                          <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                             was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                             of the containing object.</p>
                                       </div>
                                    </details>

                                    <h9 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/responsible-roles/props/ns" class="toc9 head">ns</h9>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                                    organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                    to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                    can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                    This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                    an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                    control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                    uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                    be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                    by the associated OSCAL model.
                                    <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/responsibility/responsible-role/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                              <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/responsible-roles/props/ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/responsible-roles/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>

                                    <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                                    <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/responsible-roles/props/ns</p>
                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                                    associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                          names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                          with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                       <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                          to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                       <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                                    </div>
                                 </details>

                                          <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                              <div class="header">
                                 <div>
                                    <h9 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/responsible-roles/links/href" class="toc9 head">href</h9>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                                    can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                    that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                    a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                    which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                    that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                                    is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                                    of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                                    of the document containing the link.
                                    <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/export/responsibility/responsible-role/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                                    <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/export/responsibilities/responsible-roles/links/href</p>
                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                          that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                       <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                          "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                       <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                          resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                          containing the link.</p>
                                    </div>
                                 </details>
                              </div>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props" class="toc6 head">props</h6>
                           <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">
                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                                 <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                                 <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props</p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                 qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                 may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                       OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                       or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                       and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                       an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                       lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                       consistency.</p>
                                    <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                       was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                       of the containing object.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/inherited/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">array </p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>An array  with key <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props</p>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                              or quality of the property's containing object.

                              value.

                        </div>
                     </section>
                     <section class="json-obj">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div>
                              <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/ns" class="toc7 head">ns</h7>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                              to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                              can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                              This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                              by the associated OSCAL model.
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/inherited/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                              <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/ns</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                              associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                    names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                    with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                 <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                    to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                     </section>

                     <section class="json-obj">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div>
                              <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/class" class="toc7 head">class</h7>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                              property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                              semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class
                              can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a
                              specific class value.

                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/class">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/class</a> in the object map.</p>

                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/props/class</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                              multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>

                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                                 <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                                 <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/links</p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                       a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                                    <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/inherited/link"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/links">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/links</a> in the object map.</p>

                     </div>
                     <section class="json-obj">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div>
                              <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/links/href" class="toc7 head">href</h7>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                              can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                              a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                              which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                              that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                              is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                              of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                              of the document containing the link.
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/by-component/inherited/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/links/href">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                              <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/by-components/inherited/links/href</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                    that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                 <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                    "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                 <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                    resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                    containing the link.</p>

                           <div>
